title: When does Dracula start on BBC One and who is in the cast?
text:
Claes Bang is taking on the role of the titular vampire in the creepy-looking miniseries (Picture: BBC)

The most famous vampire of them all is heading back to a screen near you very soon, as the BBC and Netflix‘s co-production of Dracula reaches us.

And it looks as if it’s going to be a pretty terrifying take on the Bram Stoker classic, with the first trailer delivering a whole lot of horror in just 30 seconds worth of footage.

If the clip is anything to go by we can expect blood, gore, satanic nuns brandishing knives and a whole lot of other creepiness when this one makes its debut.

But when is it on and who is in the cast?

Here’s what you need to know…

When does Dracula start on BBC One and will it be released on Netflix?

At the moment there’s no official start date for Dracula, although it has been confirmed as airing on BBC One.

The series will consist of three feature-length instalments, and comes to us from Mark Gatiss and Steven Moffat, who of course previously worked together on Sherlock.

It will air on Netflix outside of the UK and Ireland – with no word yet on whether it might also be released on the streaming platform here.

However, viewers will be able to catch the series on BBC iPlayer.

Who is in the cast of Dracula?

The show’s from the team that brought you Sherlock (Picture: BBC)

The cast of Dracula is led by actor Claes Bang as the titular vampire.

The Danish-born actor has been in a string of movies and TV shows in his home country, but is known outside of Denmark for the likes of The Bridge, The Girl in The Spider’s Web and The Affair.

Actress Dolly Wells (Some Girls, Noel Fielding’s Luxury Comedy) is also in the cast as Sister Agatha, while Joanna Scanlan (Hold The Sunset, Getting On) plays Mother Superior.

Other cast members include Morfydd Clark (Patrick Melrose), Sacha Dhawan (Marvel’s Iron Fist, Sherlock), Nathan Stewart-Jarrett, Jonathan Aris, Lyndsey Marshal, Chanel Cresswell, Matthew Beard and Lydia West.
